attributes.alt: Book cover for Happy in Our Skin by Fran Manushkin, illustrated by  Lauren Tobia. The cover art shows children playing at a park.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to review the letters
; engage children with a song; and introduce vocabulary
Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences; Write uppercase and lowercase letters.
Identify connections and differences between feelings and behavior.
Use possessive pronouns and subject-verb agreement; Try  to use new words and grammar.
Help children recognize and produce words with the beginning sounds of
Guide children to match letters and say their sounds.
What are the parts of our bodies? What do they do?
Can you see someone in your book who is happy in her skin?
Act like a baby! How can you show that you are unhappy? How can you show that you are happy?
What would you use to measure how long your arm is?
Write about something you liked to do when you were a baby.
Draw a picture of some happy babies.
Use crayons, markers, or letter stamps to write the letters
What can you build that a baby can play in?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely and notice when children are showing their feelings through their actions.
Identify connections and differences between feelings and behavior.
Identify their own bodies within surroundings and respect others’ personal space.
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.
Recall with children the Mind Builder.
Invite children to create two drawings, one drawing to show himself or herself as a happy baby and one to show himself or herself as a happy preK child.
What are the parts of our bodies? What do they do?
Do you see children in a book that are very young?
Show how you would help someone who fell on the playground.
Draw five happy faces. Write the number. Show the number with counters.
Write a note to someone you like to hug.
Can you make a picture of someone you like to hug?
Can you see something in the room that starts with the letter
Can you show a place where children can play happily?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build social studies background, engage children in a game of “I Spy,” and introduce vocabulary
What is special about our skin?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Identify connections and differences between feelings and behavior.
Identify unique characteristics in themselves, classmates, and children from other cultures.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.
Encourage children to use connecting cubes to make something “clever.”
Talk about what makes things alike
What are the parts of our bodies? What do they do?
Does a child in the book remind you of someone you know?
Act out how it feels when your skin is tickled.
What does our skin do after we get a cut or scrape?
Can you write a word that rhymes with
Draw a picture of your face. What color are your eyes?
Can you write or draw animals whose names start with

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas page for Head, Shoulders, Knees, and Toes. A boy is posing and words with lines point to parts of his body, including the head, eyes, ears, nose, mouth, shoulders, knees, and toes.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about our sense of touch, listen for rhyming words, and introduce vocabulary
Read closely to answer this week’s concept question:
What are the parts of our bodies? What do they do?
Identify own body within surroundings and respects others’ personal space.
Use possessive pronouns and subject-verb agreement; Try to use new words and grammar.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.
Have children follow along as you lead them to move body parts while playing Simon Says.
What are the parts of our bodies? What do they do?
On what part of the body are the eyes, ears, mouth, and nose?
With a friend, pretend you are frogs and jump! Compare who can jump farther. Who can jump higher?
Can you count your toes (on both feet)?
Think about when you were a baby. Describe what parts of your body you used to get around.
Can you trace your hand? Compare your hand with your friend’s hand. Whose hand is bigger?
Can you name things you can do with your body that start with the letters
Can you make something that bends like your knee? What did you use to make it?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to engage children actively and revisit vocabulary
How can we move in the skin we’re in?
Read and retell interactively for engagement.
Share and repeat the details in  a text.
Identify connections and differences between feelings and behavior.
Identify unique characteristics in themselves, classmates, and children from other cultures.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
How does our skin  help us?
Save children’s writing to display next week.
What are the parts of our bodies? What do they do?
What does your skin keep in? What does it keep out?
Can you perform a dance that uses all of your body parts?
Can you make a print of your pointer finger? Did you know that your fingerprint is one of a kind?
What terrific thing can you do with your body? Write about it.
Imagine something that is very soft to touch. Can you create a picture of it?
Now write those letters in lowercase.
On pages 22–23, everyone is at a block party. Pretend your classroom is having a block party! Can you work together as a group to build something for the party?
